Award Ceremony for the 2015 European Union Prize for Literature
58-Document for general distribution (intended for the general public)
The winners of this year's European Union Prize for Literature are celebrated at a gala ceremony at the Concert Noble in Brussels in the evening of 23 June.

The winning authors are presented with their awards by Tibor Navracsics, the European Commissioner for Education, Culture, Youth and Sport, in the presence of members of the European Parliament and representatives of the Latvian Presidency of the European Union.

The award recognises the best emerging authors in Europe. This year’s 12 winners, from as many European countries, are:

Carolina Schutti (Austria); Luka Bekavac (Croatia); Gaëlle Josse (France); Edina Szvoren (Hungary); Donal Ryan (Ireland); Lorenzo Amurri (Italy); Undinė Radzevičiūtė (Lithuania); Ida Hegazi Høyer (Norway); Magdalena Parys (Poland); David Machado (Portugal); Svetlana Zuchova (Slovakia) and Sara Stridsberg (Sweden).

The European Union Prize for Literature (EUPL) competition is open to the countries participating in Creative Europe. Every year, national juries in a third of the countries - 12 this year - nominate the winning authors.

Each winner receives € 5,000 and benefits from promotion and international visibility. Their publishers are encouraged to apply for EU funding to have the winning books translated into other languages to reach new markets.

Since the Prize was launched in 2009, the EU has provided funding for the translation of books by 56 (out of 59) EUPL winners, into 20 different European languages, covering a total of 203 translations - on average 3-4 translations per book.

The Creative Europe programme continues to fund translations of EUPL winning books. The winners also benefit from extra visibility at Europe's major book fairs, including Frankfurt, London, Paris, Göteborg and the Passaporta Festival in Brussels.

The EUPL is organised by the European Commission in cooperation with the European Booksellers' Federation, the European Writers' Council and the Federation of European Publishers.
